vectorData.altText: 7. The frontal and temporal lobes are separated by the __________ fissure.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
That’s right!  The frontal and temporal lobes are separated by the lateral fissure.
Lateral fissure: separates the frontal and temporal lobes.  Gently separate the edges of the lateral fissure to view the cortex of the insula     in the floor of the lateral fissure.
Median longitudinal fissure: separates the right and left cerebral hemispheres. Which dural reflection occupies this fissure      ?
Identify the following features of the superolateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere.

Transverse fissure: completely separates the cerebrum from the cerebellum. Which dural reflection occupies the transverse fissure? 
Central sulcus: separates the frontal and parietal lobes. Identify it between two parallel gyri, the precentral and postcentral gyri. 
Intraparietal sulcus: runs roughly horizontally, separating the superior parietal lobule from the inferior parietal lobule.
Parieto-occipital fissure: look for this fissure on the medial surface of the hemisphere. It extends only a short distance onto the superior aspect of the hemisphere.
Superolateral view of the right cerebral hemisphere. From Serial Dissections of the Human Brainby Carlton G. Smith, M.D., Ph.D.
If you haven’t done exercise 18.4 yet, come back and answer this question later.
